Counter-intuitively  I  think this question is as important as,  "Who will be the next president?",  "What will happen with the U.S. in the next 12 months?", and "What is the psychology of the U.S. consumer (i.e. sentiment) right now?" Here's why....   The Super Bowl doesn't really matter in this sense. (1) It's pure entertainment; (2 ) Independent of causes but correlated to historical trends

--
But both 1 & 2 are important to my propensity toward a thesis about the world 12 months from now: Entertainment
(1)  Pure entertainment has a cost.  Fortunately economist & advertisers breakdown behavior around large entertainment spectacles like the Super Bowl so some signals for a back of envelope Monet Carlo method is feasible. .........(a) Are Consumers spending more on entertainment?    ( sentiment of consumer spending & labor market since we're now at full employment )
,........(b) Are business spending on ads or otherwise around the event?  ( belief consumer sentiment is high & spending )
.........(c) What's the tolerance for counterfeit NFL merchandise is the market? ( more counterfeit = desire for low prices )
.........(d) What's the level of alcohol and drinking habits?  ( I believe alcohol & cigarettes use are signs of stress & create more stress ) Independent of causes but correlated to historical trends
(2) My propensity is the U.S. enters a recession between Fall 2016 & Fall 2017.  No big deal but given our psychology after '07-'08 that there's an over reaction. Wall Street is more likely bearish in years an old NFL team wins  - Denver Broncos.  So it'll be interesting to watch. .........(a) U.S.  financial markets are technically in a bear market now  ( there's a 53% probability a recession follows a markets bear market historically )
.........(b) Q: Macro economic stability to absorb market correction to QE?  A: NO. Contributing are currency instability, systemic instability in the largest global economies & institutions, unintended consequence of QE like strong dollar & falling treasury bond rates, Europe/China's lack of liberal market principles, and exogenous geopolitical risks in in oil, trade, etc
.........(c) In presidential election years GDP is normally up 6.5-7%  ... BUT WHEN 2 TERM PRESIDENTS ARE LEAVING the market pull back is 24-50%.  THAT'S BAD for the market but we'll see how the economy fairs  (e.g. Eisenhower, Nixon, Reagan, Bush, Obama) --

Earlier commentary/rationale Editing original forecast now that playoff teams are final (rationale/method below). I'm still favoring NFC over AFC 53% to 47% when considering all playoff teams 
When you take the playoff teams that are above the league mean yards per passing attempt, the NFC is favored 53.5 to 46.5 for the AFC. Interesting that 4 of 6 playoff teams in each conference are above the mean. When I apply the same method to the individual matchups, I get the following winners: 
Week 1 winners: KC 62-38 over HOU, CIN 50.2-49,8 over PIT, SEA 77-23 over MIN and WSH 79-21 over GB 
Week 2 winners: CIN 64-36 over NE, KC 65-35 over DEN, ARI 52-48 over SEA, and CAR 52-48 over WSH 
Week 3 winners: CIN 71-29 over KC, ARI 62-38 over CAR 
Super Bowl: ARI 51-49 over CIN So as a group and in individual matchups, I come up with the NFC. As noted in the original forecast, there are certainly some questions about this method and I'm trying it out just to see how well or poorly it works. One thing that gives me pause is that I've got CIN going to the Super Bowl and they are basically a 50-50 chance in round one vs PIT, and Andy Dalton, who is most responsible for the CIN yards per passing attempt, is not playing. That one outcome would not change my prediction, it would just substitute PIT for CIN and we'd end up with a ARI-PIT super bowl with the same winner predicted. ****** 
Original note on method: This forecast is based on yards per pass attempt, which I have read is the single best predictor of wins in football. I compared the top 4 playoff teams (as of 12/29) in the AFC and NFC based on yards per pass attempt to the league average. The top 4 AFC teams are .95 standard deviations above the league mean, while the top 4 NFC teams are 1.24 standard deviations above the league mean. The difference in these results using a standard normal distribution is a 6% edge to the NFC. Based on the yards per attempt numbers, the top playoff teams are 1) Arizona 2) Cincinnati 3) Seattle 4) Pittsburgh, which raises some questions about this forecasting method - for example, what role does defense play, will Dalton be ready to play for Cincinnati, and will Pittsburgh even make the playoffs. I'll adjust the forecast when the playoff teams are set - barring major changes in yards per attempt exiting week 17, if Pittsburgh does not make the playoffs, it will increase the NFC's chances to 58%.

I based my prediction on the following game features: 1) Turnovers committed (by offense)
2) Interceptions by defense
3) Balance between passing and running game
4) Possession time
5) The penalty yards
6) Total yards In particular, I used the performance of the two teams throughout the year and using bootstrap I simulated their performance in the super bowl.  I also built a logistic regression model using data from the last 7 NFL seasons to quantify the importance of these factors for the probability of winning.  All these give Panthers a higher probability of winning by 36%  More details for my approach can be found in this technical report: http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.04302

When you take the playoff teams that are above the league mean yards per passing attempt, the NFC is favored 53.5 to 46.5 for the AFC. Interesting that 4 of 6 playoff teams in each conference are above the mean. When I apply the same method to the individual matchups, I get the following winners: 
Week 1 winners: KC 62-38 over HOU, CIN 50.2-49,8 over PIT, SEA 77-23 over MIN and WSH 79-21 over GB 
Week 2 winners: CIN 64-36 over NE, KC 65-35 over DEN, ARI 52-48 over SEA, and CAR 52-48 over WSH

As noted in the original forecast, there are certainly some questions about this method and I'm trying it out just to see how well or poorly it works. One thing that gives me pause is that I've got CIN going to the Super Bowl and they are basically a 50-50 chance in round one vs PIT, and Andy Dalton, who is most responsible for the CIN yards per passing attempt, is not playing. That one outcome would not change my prediction, it would just substitute PIT for CIN and we'd end up with a ARI-PIT super bowl with the same winner predicted. ****** 
Original note on method: This forecast is based on yards per pass attempt, which I have read is the single best predictor of wins in football. I compared the top 4 playoff teams (as of 12/29) in the AFC and NFC based on yards per pass attempt to the league average. The top 4 AFC teams are .95 standard deviations above the league mean, while the top 4 NFC teams are 1.24 standard deviations above the league mean. The difference in these results using a standard normal distribution is a 6% edge to the NFC. Based on the yards per attempt numbers, the top playoff teams are 1) Arizona 2) Cincinnati 3) Seattle 4) Pittsburgh, which raises some questions about this forecasting method - for example, what role does defense play, will Dalton be ready to play for Cincinnati, and will Pittsburgh even make the playoffs. I'll adjust the forecast when the playoff teams are set - barring major changes in yards per attempt exiting week 17, if Pittsburgh does not make the playoffs, it will increase the NFC's chances to 58%.

I'm a newbie here, so didn't plan to forecast football outcome, owing to lack of (much) knowledge.  I'm a casual fan at best.  But then I figured that the reason I'm here is to learn to be a better forecaster, and not just for things I know well.  In my mind, the source most likely to be reliable is the one having both expertise, experience, and skin in the game, so I thought of bookies.  (I thought for a moment it would be 'cheating' to use others' predictions, but on second thought see using bookies' predictions as no different than other data having predictive value). So... I went to this site:  http://www.vegasinsider.com/nfl/odds/futures/ to get their "ODDS TO WIN 2015 SUPER BOWL L". I converted those odds to implied percentages using the "Odds Converter Tool" at this site:  http://www.bettingexpert.com/blog/how-to-convert-odds. I then summed all the implied odds (they totaled 111.4%) because I don't know if (and if so how) a "bookies' profit" (or whatever the real term) may be built into these odds. I then summed the odds for all AFC teams and for all NFC teams and divided each by 111.4%.  Result:  AFC = 0.486 and NFC = 0.514. Does this make sense? To do:
- Update after each week's games.
- Look at a few times during the week to see the degree to which odds change within week.
- Find out if the "Vegas Insider" site is a reliable indicator of odds (Does anyone know?)
- Find out if conversion of odds to implied probability is appropriate (and why it adds up to 111.4% this week)
- Think about what information I might find that bookies don't incorporate into their odds.

Upping NFC to 86 (from 80). The playoff picture is set --> http://www.sbnation.com/a/nfl-playoff-bracket-2016 And the Elo ratings are updated --> http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2015-nfl-predictions/ Now that we're into playoffs, what's key is the matchups. The *best* team to make the playoffs doesn't always win the Super Bowl, especially if they run into an opponent that has their number. The four teams that are moving onto NEXT weekend's games (Denver, NE, Carolina, and Arizona). The matchups this weekend (with a quick prediction): Seattle @ Minnesota: Minny's D looked GREAT last night against the Packers, but the Packers have been having an off-year. Notably, Seattle beat up on Minny in early December (http://www.si.com/nfl/game/2015/12/06/seahawks-vikings-sunday-december-6th-2015). It's all a "different ball game" once you're in the playoffs (or so the #narratives would tell us). According to the Elo ratings, Seattle is a MUCH stronger team than Minny. SEATTLE wins by at least a TD. GB @ Washington: Washington is the NFC East's representative in the playoffs this season. The NFC East (this season) is not what it used to be. According to Elo ratings, GB is a MUCH stronger team. GB wins by at least a FG. KC @ HOU: Probably the most lopsided matchup of the games this weekend. KC scored nearly 100 points (!) more than Houston this year and allowed almost 40 fewer points. KC has won 10 (!) straight games. HOU is fortunate that its last two games of the year were against two of the worst teams this season (TEN and JAX) or else IND would probably be in this game and not HOU. KC's Elo score blows HOU's out of the water. KC wins by at least TWO TDs. PIT @ CIN: This is the only game where (to my mind) there is some ambiguity. Cincy's performance this season is, in part, tied to the success of their QB, Andy Dalton, but Dalton has been hurt the last little bit. There's talk that he might be able to play this weekend. Even if he plays, there'll be questions about his health (#narratives -- again). Anyway, even if he plays, I still give the edge to Pittsburgh (their Elo scores are essentially the same, Pitt's is higher by 10). If Dalton plays, PIT by a FG, if Dalton doesn't play, PIT by a TD. ~~~~ Assuming things go as I've predicted above, that leaves the next 4 games as: GB @ AZ
SEA @ CAR KC @ NE
PIT @ DEN On the NFC side, I'm far more confident that one of AZ, SEA, or CAR will reach the Super Bowl (and all three of those teams are strong). In fact, they all have the three highest Elo scores right now! On the AFC side, those two games are wide open! NE has been sliding and Denver "backed" into the #1 seed (is that even possible?) Did I mention that both the #5 and #6 seeds in the AFC have beaten the #1 seed in the AFC!? And that NE, after starting the season 10-0, has gone 2-4? Yeah, if there were ever a year where it seemed clear that the NFC were poised to regain its title as Super Bowl champions, this would be that year.  ~~ I'll check back on Saturday and Sunday night.

Sunday was exciting and there were quite a few things to talk about. I'll start with the NFC. The Vikings beat the Packers. I had the Packers as a contender (and still do) but the Vikings looked good and took the NFC North. We'll see the Packers take on the Redskins next and I imagine they'll get through them. Vikings are added as outside shots.  Speaking of the Redskins...not Superbowl contenders. Cardinals lost and badly. The Seahawks are dangerous and I'll keep them on my radar. They did lose to the Rams but other than that they actually have had a pretty good year. I've ignored them until now but think they deserve to be in the running as contenders. Finally, the NFC South. The Panthers still look good and are still favorites. This leaves the NFC with the Panthers, Cardinals, Seakhawks, Packers (kind of) and Vikings (kind of) as contenders.  On to the AFC. The Patriots look bad. Unless injuries are no longer an issue in the playoffs, I don't see them as having a chance at winning it all. I'll keep them but with an outside shot. Broncos clinched home field advantage and Peyton is back!!! They started out with a rocky start but looked great in the second half. Definitely keeping them as contenders. First, let's group likely playoff teams into two groups: contenders (Arizona, Carolina, and New England) and pretenders (everyone else). There are four possible  Super Bowl match ups: contender v. contender, NFC contender v. AFC pretender, AFC contender v. NFC pretender, and pretender v. pretender. Let's assume that a contender will always be favored against a pretender and that pretender-pretender and contender-contender match-ups would be even odds. The NFC's superior championship odds are mainly a function of the fact that it is much more likely that a NFC contender matches up against an AFC pretender. Because the Patriots are the only AFC contender, it is much more likely they would be upset than having both Carolina and Arizona not advance to the Super Bowl. I assumed that contenders would be 55% favorites in match-ups against pretenders but, even dropping that percentage to 51%, the NFC would still be a 55% favorite.

This forecast is based on yards per pass attempt, which I have read is the single best predictor of wins in football.  I compared the top 4 playoff teams (as of 12/29) in the AFC and NFC based on yards per pass attempt to the league average. The top 4 AFC teams are .95 standard deviations above the league mean, while the top 4 NFC teams are 1.24 standard deviations above the league mean. The difference in these results using a standard normal distribution is a 6% edge to the NFC. Based on the yards per attempt numbers, the top playoff teams are 1) Arizona 2) Cincinnati 3) Seattle 4) Pittsburgh, which raises some questions about this forecasting method - for example, what role does defense play, will Dalton be ready to play for Cincinnati, and will Pittsburgh even make the playoffs.  I'll adjust the forecast when the playoff teams are set - barring major changes in yards per attempt exiting week 17, if Pittsburgh does not make the playoffs, it will increase the NFC's chances to 58%.

The implied probabilities in betting odds (betfair.com) point ot the following favourites:
New England Patriots (AFC)  - 21%

Seattle Seahawks (NFC) - 11%
Packers (NFC) - 8%
Broncos (AFC) - 7%

Green Bay and Arizona do not have that as we head into December and this is North Carolina's first trip into this territory (experience is such a key factor).  New England appears to have made it through its major injury issues, Cincinnati is playing consistently and Kansas City has experience.  AFC, most likely New England, will beat NFC, either Green Bay or North Carolina, in the Super Bowl is the forecast at 75 - 25.

I used Nate Silver's current model results for the probability of each of the top six teams winning the super bowl and weighted the conferences by summing the percentages, then used the ratio for the prediction.

AFC has the stronger teams, based on excellence in coaching and play.  The latter can change.  Gronkowski's injury reduced my prediction from 95% AFC to 90% AFC - because G. plays a huge role in the success of the strongest AFC team.
The strongest teams are in the AFC at this time. I'll probably change this score as things change, but at the moment, this is the way I'm going.

Any Given Sunday holds true throughout the playoffs for 4 weeks of games - that said current Vegas odds for the Patriots are 3/1 (AFC) and for Cardinals and Panthers both at 11/2 (both NFC) and for Denver Broncos 10/1 (AFC) and if you go down the list of increasing odds the cumulative odds for the AFC vs NFC is fairly even though the AFC is more of a longshot than the NFC in the top current 16 favored teams. But the cumulative odds equation is too difficult and time consuming for me to attempt currently and I am using a bias and "guessing" that it is not much more than a flip of a coin if you compound all of the probabilities and then weight subjectively for current power rankings and the number of variables that can change are just too many even in this short window of time (for instance Tom Brady could get injured or Cam Newton that would vastly affect the probabilistic outcomes). I also don't aggregate to 100% because while it is clearly less than 1% chance there is still the remotest of possibilities that the Super Bowl is not played due to a black swan event and even though the probability of such an event of such magnitude happening is probabily less than even 1/10th of a percent, I did want to give voice to the likelihood of neither winning is >0.

Panthers 84% because I really don't think any team in the NFC will beat them in the playoffs. I think the only team in the AFC that can beat them is the Patriots if Gronk, Amendola and Edelman (miracously) return healthy. However, I don't think they will make it pass the Broncos and the Broncos do not have any decisive advantage over the Panthers. The Panthers have to play three games to win it all (66%/game), if healthy Patriots make it (33%), but I think Broncos will make it so I cut their percentage in half and gave it to the Panthers. The Panthers at this moment, runs a highly efficient run first option offense and has deep ball receivers. Their front seven can handle the run themselves against most teams, which allows the Panthers to keep two deep safeties over the top to protect the deep pass. This is every defensive coordinator's dream scenario. The only team I suspect that can probably force the Panthers to bring an eighth man into the box is the Vikings because of Adrian Peterson. However, the Panthers have a CB in Norman that can lock up their deep threat Stefan Diggs, and possibly shift the free safety over the top of Wallace. Kuechly can cover lots of ground in the mid-deep middle. As for the other NFC teams, I don't think pass heavy teams like the Packers will do well against the Panthers. Seattle will be my dark horse to upset the Panthers because they have speed on their defense, an offense that is similar to the Panthers, and Russell Wilson who can extend plays (nightmare to defensive coordinators), but they have to make the playoffs first. The AFC is a big question mark. The Patriots are by far the best team in the AFC (followed by the Broncos and Bengals), but losing Gronk, Edelman, and Amendola for the next couple of weeks forces them to become a run team. They have to face three great teams against the run (NYJ, Ten, and Hou). These are games where they will have a higher chance of losing, which I have a feeling, Denver or Cincinnati will take home field advantage in the playoffs. Unfortunately, if the Patriots have to play against Denver at home, I think they will lose. The Denver crowd will force Brady to make less adjustments at the line because of crowd noise. Denver plays a lot of man defense and has great pass rushers which is a benefit to the secondary because they don't have to stay in coverage too long. This is a major issue for the pass because Edelman was really the only guy that can get off press coverage quickly. I think the Patriots lose and the Patriots are a much better match up against the Panthers. Hopefully, this much amount of analysis extends over to different questions. (I was a football coach once.)

Patriots have too many injuries; Brock Ostweiler has given new energy to Broncos, so team can feel secure if Manning cannot play, and still have time to address lack of consistency in the offense. Seahawks will still be a strong challenge but their QB strength will wane as season continues and injuries begin to take a toll.

Romo certainly has his detractors, but he's proven that he's one of the better QBs in the league over the last decade. Granted, he was just coming off an injury (and fell prey to it again), I was thoroughly impressed with the way Carolina played Defense against him and the rest of the Cowboys.  Maybe it's just me, but it seems that there really aren't any "superstars" on Carolina's team. Yes, there's Cam Newton, but my impression is that he's not written about in the same way that Brady is, Brees (was), E. Manning (is), or P. Manning (was). Maybe I'm not following the NFL as closely as I used to, or maybe it's a subtle bit of racism (?), but it seems like the Panthers are more like a "team" in that feature player. Further to that, the Panthers' RB is not half bad, either (currently 3rd in the league in rushing) and when it comes time to salt away the game, an important resource to have. The rest of the NFC, to my eyes (and quick glance of the stats), seems more impressive than the Cincy/Denver combination. The Cardinals are really good at putting up points (seven of their eleven games have seen them score more than 30 points). To that end, two of their stars on offense are certainly part of that (C. Palmer, 4th in the league in passing yards, and C. Johnson, 4th in the league in rushing yards). Similarly, Minnesota (and the Adrian Peterson show, who has almost 200 more rushing yards than the person second in the league) is looking pretty good, especially after AP shredded the Falcons' number one run defense. I think we'll learn more about Minny/Arizona when they play each other next Thursday night (Dec. 10). There's also GB, who are perennial contenders, and Seattle's turned things around recently (who would want to face a streaking Seahawks team?) Of course, this will need to be revisited again next Monday, but after this weekend's games, it seems to me that the collection of contenders on the NFC side are pulling away from the collection of contenders on the AFC side. ~~~

The reason I only went back to 08 is because the deeper into recent history we go, the less the teams look like the current iterations. Going back to 08 might even be too far. Even going back to 2010, the NFC's "winning" 4 out of the last 6.  However, to that argument, maybe we're in a shift.
